search_result.title: Eclipse myths busted by NASA, other experts as Delaware ...
search_result.text:
From ancient civilizations predicting celestial events without telescopes to Donald Trump gazing at the sun with his naked eyes, humanity's fascination with solar eclipses spans many generations.

Excitement peaks in the United States as the next total solar eclipse is Monday, April 8, the first since 2017. This event is huge because there won't be another in the United States until 2044.

But first, we need to make sure everyone knows the facts about eclipses, because there are crazy myths floating around that have been debunked. We also share where to buy the appropriate eclipse glasses.

Pregnant women shouldn't watch an eclipse since it could hurt the baby

There's a false idea out there that harmful radiation is released from an eclipse, which has been debunked by NASA.

Greg Weaver, manager of Mt. Cuba Astronomical Observatory in Hockessin, said this myth makes no sense.

"It's like saying, 'If you're pregnant, you shouldn't go out in the sun, because you might get a sunburn and it might hurt your pregnant child.' That's crazy," he explained.

An eclipse is a bad omen

While an eclipse can seem eerie, they're not a sign of bad luck.

Weaver said that superstition may stem from around 900 A.D. when ancient civilizations such as the Mayans used to accurately predict eclipses. They understood what are called the SAROS cycles, which are periods of the moon going around the earth.

"If you were like an astronomer and you failed to predict an eclipse, that was a death sentence, because that was your job," Weaver explained.

NASA says the idea of eclipses being tied to bad omens is a classic case of "confirmation basis," in which psychologists say we tend to remember moments when two things happened together but forget when they don't.

One example NASA gives is that King Henry I of England died in A.D. 1133, an event that coincided with a total solar eclipse.

Total solar eclipse can't happen at North or South Pole

The last total solar eclipse seen from the North Pole area was on March 20, 2015 and it passed over the North Pole itself and it came to an end exactly at the Spring Equinox, per NASA. The last total solar eclipse seen from the South Pole area was on Nov. 23, 2003.

Weaver said a total solar eclipse is once again slated to pass over the North Pole area on Aug. 12, 2026 and will pass through parts of Iceland, Greenland and Siberia. In 2039, a total solar eclipse is headed to the South Pole and will pass over Antarctica, he added.

"They can happen anywhere," Weaver said about eclipses.

Total solar eclipse can make you blind

Your eyes won't get damaged if you're in the direct path of a total eclipse and you're not wearing solar glasses during that phase because the sky will be too dark to see it, said Weaver, who is traveling to Indiana to witness the total eclipse on April 8, since Delaware will only experience a partial phase of the solar event.

At all other phases of a solar eclipse, proper precautions to protect your eyes from damage are needed.

"Except during the brief total phase of a total solar eclipse, when the Moon completely blocks the Sun’s bright face, it is not safe to look directly at the Sun without specialized eye protection for solar viewing,'' reports NASA on its website.

So why didn't Donald Trump go blind when he looked at the eclipse?

During Donald Trump's presidency in 2017, the internet buzzed when he observed a partial phase of a total eclipse from the White House balcony without protective glasses. Many questioned why he didn't suffer blindness from looking at the sun directly.

Weaver said the answer is simple.

"It's just like looking at the sun on a sunny day. Try staring at the sun. You can't. Your blink reflexes will shut your eyes because it'll damage your eyes," explained Weaver, who traveled with his wife to Tennessee in 2017 to get a better view of the total eclipse.

To the Mt. Cuba expert's point, Trump squinted at the sun twice for a grand total of less than 2 seconds, before wearing his protective glasses.

But don't try this at home, kids. Experts advise that you keep your vision intact by using precautions such as eclipse glasses throughout the event.

"There's no word from the White House about whether Trump suffered eye damage, but he appeared to look up for only a brief moment,'' say the folks at Space.com. "If you plan to look at the sun during an eclipse or at any other time, make sure you put on a pair of protective glasses or use a pinhole projector.''

Will I need solar glasses for the total eclipse?

Most people around the country will need to wear special eye protection to view the eclipse since most won't be in the path of totality, which is when the moon completely blocks the sun's bright face, NASA says.

"Except during the brief total phase of a total solar eclipse, when the Moon completely blocks the Sun’s bright face, it is not safe to look directly at the Sun without specialized eye protection for solar viewing,'' experts warn on the website.

Delawareans will experience a partial eclipse, and this means the sun will be too bright to look at directly without using appropriate eye protection.

Eclipse glasses aren't regular sunglasses since they're "thousands of times darker and ought to comply with the ISO 12312-2 international standard," NASA says.

"Viewing any part of the bright Sun through a camera lens, binoculars, or a telescope without a special-purpose solar filter secured over the front of the optics will instantly cause severe eye injury.''

Where can I buy eclipse glasses?

While NASA reported it "does not approve any particular brand of solar glasses," its website does link to the American Astronomical Society's website.

The AAS said several "counterfeit eclipse glasses" flooded the marketplace during the 2017 eclipse. In response to that, the AAS has a list of reputable sellers at eclipse.aas.org that people can vet.

In addition, the AAS says it doesn't recommend searching for eclipse glasses on Amazon, eBay, Temu, or any other online marketplace and buying from whichever vendor offers the lowest price. Instead, they recommend that people make sure that (1) the seller is identified on their AAS site and (2) the seller is listed on their page.

Wanna see the solar eclipse in Delaware?Here's where to check it out

Want a better view of the solar eclipse?These places are good to see it out of state

When is the next solar eclipse?

The next total eclipse in the US is Monday, April 8.

In Delaware:

Partial eclipse begins at 2:07 p.m.

Maximum eclipse begins at 3:23 p.m.

Partial eclipse ends at 4:34 p.m.

The total solar eclipse will be visible at 4:41 p.m., which only 0.55% of the population, or 43.8 million people, will be able to see worldwide in areas where the eclipse is visible. As for any part of the eclipse, not just totality, 8.19% of the population, or 652 million people, will be able to tune in, according to TimeandDate.com.

Few celestial events have the power to capture our collective attention the way this upcoming total solar eclipse has managed to do. And for those making time to witness it, two questions are bound to be on their mind: Will totality reach my area and if so, how long will the resulting darkness last?

Most people across the country are bound to experience the eclipse in some form, but only 13 states fall directly on the path of totality, where the moon will appear large enough to shield all but the sun's outermost layer, the corona.

As you make your eclipse-viewing plans, these interactive maps should help you chart the time and duration for when totality will occur in cities along the path.

search_result.title: The April total solar eclipse will create dangerous, crowded traffic
search_result.text:
Editor's note: An updated cloud forecast for the April 2024 total solar eclipse is in. Read the latest eclipse forecast and news as of Wednesday, April 3.

Millions of Americans will be looking to the sky during a rare total solar eclipse on April 8, and experts warn the excitement could create dangerous and busy traffic conditions as people pack into the narrow band of the country with the best view.

"Pack your patience, whether traveling a great distance or locally, people will be out and about to catch a glimpse of the eclipse," said Aixa Diaz, a spokesperson for the American Automobile Association.

Roads could be especially packed at the center of the eclipse's path as Americans who want the best view crowd into cities, towns and remote areas, many without the infrastructure to handle big crowds.

A similar scenario played out in 2017 during the nation's last total solar eclipse, where congestion in some areas lasted for up to 13 hours after the totality of the eclipse, according to Transportation Research News, a National Research Council publication. An analysis of traffic patterns from that year suggests that the worst of the traffic – both on big interstates and rural backroads – will kick off after the eclipse ends and everyone tries to exit all at once.

This year, in Ohio's Lorain County, county officials are warning residents to be aware about the increase in visitors, traffic and jammed roads – and possible cellphone signal drops.

“What we could have is crowds here that we’re not used to,” wrote Dave Freeman, the director of Lorain County Emergency Management. “We’re not set up infrastructure-wise for that, we don’t have the roads.”

Eclipse forecast:Will the 2024 eclipse still look good if it's cloudy? What to know about cloud forecasts.

Where will traffic be the worst during 2024 total solar eclipse?

Roads in states where sky gazers will travel to see the centerline of totality will be most prone to traffic jams.

Even though Oklahoma only has a small corner of the state in the path of totality, the state "is expected to receive an influx of anywhere from 17,000 to 66,000 visitors to watch the solar eclipse," reads an announcement from Oklahoma Highway Patrol. Officials there are warning residents "the large influx of visitors to southeastern Oklahoma could overwhelm and backup the area's road systems," including two-lane highways passing through small towns.

They advise residents to expect hotels and visiting areas at maximum capacity, increased traffic and delays in deliveries.

The last total solar eclipse snarled US traffic

Wyoming Department of Transportation spokesman Doug McGee said more than 536,000 cars filled the state's streets after the eclipse in 2017 and the state highway system "was taxed like it’s never been before," The Denver Post reported.

And "travel from Casper, Wyoming, to Denver, Colorado – normally a 4-hour trip – took 10 hours or more," according to an analysis of traffic from Transportation Research News.

The analysis' author Jonathan Upchurch said most sky gazers traveled to the paths of totality by car, "roadways experienced very little traffic congestion on the days leading up to totality" and "almost every Interstate route passing through the path of totality showed red on Google Traffic maps" after the eclipse reached totality.

The 2017 traffic woes followed warnings from officials.

Be careful if you're driving during the eclipse

Texas state officials are also warning drivers to "be on alert for distracted pedestrians looking to the sky." They also say drivers should not wear eclipse glasses, which block out most light, while driving.

What time is the solar eclipse?Search your ZIP code for a viewing guide

Officials there and elsewhere along the solar eclipse's line of totality are recommending drivers keep their headlights on, be mindful of pedestrians on the road and even stock up on essentials like fuel and food ahead of the eclipse.

AAA, which insures drivers across the country, is also warning people that sky gazers looking for a good view of the eclipse will be on the roads. They recommend drivers put their sun visors in their cars down to block their view of the sun and watch closely for pedestrian traffic.

How should Americans prepare for traffic jams?

AAA and the Oklahoma Highway Patrol suggest several ways Americans can prepare for traffic jams related to the solar eclipse:

Plan ahead so you don't have to travel for errands or appointments around when the eclipse is happening.

Don't pull over on the side of a road or highway to view the eclipse. Find a parking area instead.

Fuel up before the eclipse and have some essentials on hand while traveling.

When and where can you view the 2024 total solar eclipse?

A total solar eclipse happens when the moon blocks the sun's light, leading to a period of partial or full darkness on Earth.

The path of totality, where the sun is fully blocked, in the U.S. begins in Texas and the eclipse starts around 1:27 p.m. local time.

Cities on the centerline of the April 8 eclipse include Dallas, Cleveland and Buffalo, New York, according to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

search_result.title: Total solar eclipse 2024 path of totality: What states can see it
search_result.text:
Monday is your last shot of witnessing a total solar eclipse in North America for 20 years. Fortunately, the path of totality in the U.S. crosses from the bottom of Texas all the way to the tip of Maine, giving many Americans a good chance of finding a place within a reasonable distance to skygaze.

Even those who find themselves in a location in the continental United States outside the eclipse's direct path are likely to witness the stunning celestial event in some form. But when it comes to experiencing a total solar eclipse as rare and grandiose as the one days away, there's no doubt about it: The path of totality is the place to be.

Here's what to know about the 2024 total solar eclipse's path of totality, including the times and durations when darkness is expected to fall.

Solar eclipse experiment:Here's why NASA is launching 3 sounding rockets into space during the total solar eclipse

What is the path of totality?

Those in the direct line of the eclipse will be treated to an incredible sight as the moon completely blots out the sun's disk, ushering in uncharacteristic darkness and revealing the sun's elusive outermost layer called the corona. That moment is called "totality" and this year the path of totality crosses through 13 U.S. states.

The last total solar eclipse to cut through North America was in 2017. But astronomers say there won't be any comparison between that eclipse and the one coming Monday. For the 2024 eclipse, the corona will be brighter, the moon will appear larger and totality will last just a bit longer than it did seven years ago.

What U.S. cities and states are on the path of totality?

The 115-mile-wide eclipse will provide millions of spectators with a front row seat to its majesty as it passes through Mexico, the United States and Canada.

In the U.S., hundreds of cities and small towns fall directly on the path of totality. An estimated 31 million Americans already live on the path this year, compared to just 12 million in 2017, according to eclipse cartographer Michael Zeiler at GreatAmericanEclipse.com.

Here are some of the major cities in each of the 13 states:

Dallas and San Antonio, Texas

Idabel, Oklahoma

Poplar Bluff, Missouri

Little Rock, Arkansas

Paducah, Kentucky

Indianapolis and Evansville, Indiana

Carbondale, Illinois

Cleveland and Toledo, Ohio

Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, New York

Burlington, Vermont

Lancaster, New Hampshire

Caribou, Maine

Erie, Pennsylvania

Additionally, small parts of Tennessee and Michigan are also expected to experience the eclipse, NASA says. In the United States, the eclipse's path will end in Maine before visiting the maritime provinces of Canada, according to estimates.

What time will totality occur in the United States?

Mexico's Pacific coast will be the first location in continental North America to experience totality, which will occur at about 11:07 a.m. PDT, according to NASA.

As the moon's shadow travels northeast, totality in the U.S. will begin at 1:27 p.m. CDT in Eagle Pass, Texas. From there, the path will cut diagonally across the country before ending around 3:33 p.m. EDT in Lee, Maine, according to nationaleclipse.com.

Along the way, periods of darkness could last a mere few seconds or, in some cities, could surpass four minutes.

Here are the major cities in each state where you can expect to experience totality in the United States (note that the included times do not account for when the partial eclipse begins and ends):

Dallas, Texas: 1:40-1:44 p.m. CDT

Idabel, Oklahoma: 1:45-1:49 p.m. CDT

Little Rock, Arkansas: 1:51-1:54 p.m. CDT

Poplar Bluff, Missouri: 1:56-2:00 p.m. CDT

Paducah, Kentucky: 2-2:02 p.m. CDT

Carbondale, Illinois: 1:59-2:03 p.m. CDT

Evansville, Indiana: 2:02-2:05 p.m. CDT

Cleveland, Ohio: 3:13-3:17 p.m. EDT

Erie, Pennsylvania: 3:16-3:20 p.m. EDT

Buffalo, New York: 3:18-3:22 p.m. EDT

Burlington, Vermont: 3:26-3:29 p.m. EDT

Lancaster, New Hampshire: 3:27-3:30 p.m. EDT

Caribou, Maine: 3:32-3:34 p.m. EDT

Did the path of totality change?

A new map from an amateur astronomer is projecting that the path of totality for Monday's solar eclipse may be narrower than experts previously believed.

If it's correct, some places, including several cities in Ohio, may now miss out on totality, while other places, including some additional cities in Texas, may now experience it.

But even if the new calculation is more accurate, it’ll likely be such a miniscule difference that it's unlikely to matter much for most of the millions of people who hope to witness the eclipse.

In fact, a NASA spokesperson told the Detroit Free Press that the U.S. space agency won't be making any alterations to its own calculations.

Do you need eclipse glasses during totality?

A total solar eclipse offers skygazers the rare opportunity to witness the eclipse with the naked eye. However, solar eclipse glasses are still needed until totality is reached.

Certified solar eclipse glasses are crucial for spectators to avoid the sun's retina-damaging rays. But when the moon moves completely in front of the sun and blocks its light, you'll know it's safe to remove the glasses for a short period of time.

Here's what to know about the 2024 total solar eclipse's path of totality, including the times and durations when darkness is expected to fall.

Solar eclipse experiment:Here's why NASA is launching 3 sounding rockets into space during the total solar eclipse

What is the path of totality?

Those in the direct line of the eclipse will be treated to an incredible sight as the moon completely blots out the sun's disk, ushering in uncharacteristic darkness and revealing the sun's elusive outermost layer called the corona. That moment is called "totality" and this year the path of totality crosses through 13 U.S. states.

The last total solar eclipse to cut through North America was in 2017. But astronomers say there won't be any comparison between that eclipse and the one coming Monday. For the 2024 eclipse, the corona will be brighter, the moon will appear larger and totality will last just a bit longer than it did seven years ago.

What U.S. cities and states are on the path of totality?

The 115-mile-wide eclipse will provide millions of spectators with a front row seat to its majesty as it passes through Mexico, the United States and Canada.

In the U.S., hundreds of cities and small towns fall directly on the path of totality. An estimated 31 million Americans already live on the path this year, compared to just 12 million in 2017, according to eclipse cartographer Michael Zeiler at GreatAmericanEclipse.com.

Here are some of the major cities in each of the 13 states:

Dallas and San Antonio, Texas

Idabel, Oklahoma

Poplar Bluff, Missouri

Little Rock, Arkansas

Paducah, Kentucky

Indianapolis and Evansville, Indiana

Carbondale, Illinois

Cleveland and Toledo, Ohio

Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, New York

Burlington, Vermont

Lancaster, New Hampshire

Caribou, Maine

Erie, Pennsylvania

Additionally, small parts of Tennessee and Michigan are also expected to experience the eclipse, NASA says. In the United States, the eclipse's path will end in Maine before visiting the maritime provinces of Canada, according to estimates.

What time will totality occur in the United States?

Mexico's Pacific coast will be the first location in continental North America to experience totality, which will occur at about 11:07 a.m. PDT, according to NASA.

As the moon's shadow travels northeast, totality in the U.S. will begin at 1:27 p.m. CDT in Eagle Pass, Texas. From there, the path will cut diagonally across the country before ending around 3:33 p.m. EDT in Lee, Maine, according to nationaleclipse.com.

Along the way, periods of darkness could last a mere few seconds or, in some cities, could surpass four minutes.

Here are the major cities in each state where you can expect to experience totality in the United States (note that the included times do not account for when the partial eclipse begins and ends):

Dallas, Texas: 1:40-1:44 p.m. CDT

Idabel, Oklahoma: 1:45-1:49 p.m. CDT

Little Rock, Arkansas: 1:51-1:54 p.m. CDT

Poplar Bluff, Missouri: 1:56-2:00 p.m. CDT

Paducah, Kentucky: 2-2:02 p.m. CDT

Carbondale, Illinois: 1:59-2:03 p.m. CDT

Evansville, Indiana: 2:02-2:05 p.m. CDT

Cleveland, Ohio: 3:13-3:17 p.m. EDT

Erie, Pennsylvania: 3:16-3:20 p.m. EDT

Buffalo, New York: 3:18-3:22 p.m. EDT

Burlington, Vermont: 3:26-3:29 p.m. EDT

Lancaster, New Hampshire: 3:27-3:30 p.m. EDT

Caribou, Maine: 3:32-3:34 p.m. EDT

Did the path of totality change?

A new map from an amateur astronomer is projecting that the path of totality for Monday's solar eclipse may be narrower than experts previously believed.

If it's correct, some places, including several cities in Ohio, may now miss out on totality, while other places, including some additional cities in Texas, may now experience it.

But even if the new calculation is more accurate, it’ll likely be such a miniscule difference that it's unlikely to matter much for most of the millions of people who hope to witness the eclipse.

In fact, a NASA spokesperson told the Detroit Free Press that the U.S. space agency won't be making any alterations to its own calculations.

Do you need eclipse glasses during totality?

A total solar eclipse offers skygazers the rare opportunity to witness the eclipse with the naked eye. However, solar eclipse glasses are still needed until totality is reached.

Certified solar eclipse glasses are crucial for spectators to avoid the sun's retina-damaging rays. But when the moon moves completely in front of the sun and blocks its light, you'll know it's safe to remove the glasses for a short period of time.

Eric Lagatta covers breaking and trending news for USA TODAY. Reach him at elagatta@gannett.com

search_result.title: Eclipse 2024 events near me: A list of public festivities on April 8
search_result.text:
On April 8, the moon will obscure the entire face of the sun, resulting in a few minutes-long transformation of day into night. Over a dozenluckyU.S. states are located in the eclipse’s path of totality, spanning from Texas to Maine – and they’re getting ready to welcome travelers for the exceptional natural phenomenon.

Experts expect up to 4 million people to tune in to this year's total solar eclipse, mainly because it will be two minutes longer than 2017’s, according to HotelPlanner CEO Tim Hentschel.

“Simply put, this will be one of the most viewed celestial events in history,” he said in a statement.

Since the eclipse occurs on a Monday, Hentschel says most travelers will make a long weekend of it.

Adding even more excitement is that the next total solar eclipse won’t be for another 20 years.

Learn more: Best travel insurance

Travelers who want to see the celestial event can choose from a number of celebrations and viewing parties across the country. These range from an event that also brings awareness to what life is like for the visually impaired in Rochester, New York, to a chance to learn about astronomy from an Indigenous perspective to a viewing with NASA in the “Racing Capital of the World.”

Here’s a list of some of the major events for the total solar eclipse on April 8 in New York, Texas, Indiana, Kentucky, Ohio, Arkansas, Illinois, Maine, Pennsylvania and Washington, D.C.

Want to see the total solar eclipse?You can see it from national parks, but their skies offer much more

New York eclipse public events

▶ People in Rochester will experience the total solar eclipse for three minutes and 38 seconds, and the city is hosting a slew of events April 6-8. On the day of the eclipse, there will be a free Rochester Public Market with entertainment, beer and chocolate tastings and sensory-friendly spaces. ROC the Eclipse Festival will celebrate the total solar eclipse with a three-day festival April 6-8 at the Rochester Museum and Science Center featuring hands-on activities, speakers, live entertainment, eclipse merchandise, food trucks and more.

▶ The Strong National Museum of Play in Rochester will celebrate the 2024 eclipse with three days of festivities themed around playing with light. Guests will be able to create art on a Lite-Brite-like board, craft a kaleidoscope, make shadow puppets in a shadow puppet theater and more.

▶ On April 8 at Genesee Valley Field House in Rochester, there will be events and activities to help people better understand what life is like with “partial or total occlusion every day.” These hands-on events include light sound box interpreting, tactile exhibits, space science experts, audio darts, tandem biking, guide training, beep baseball, tactile map-building, audio description, free tax preparation and 3D printing.

▶ Genesee Country Village & Museum in Rochester will offer the opportunity to experience totality in a 19th-century historic village April 5-7.

▶ Niagara Falls is partnering with NASA on a series of free eclipse events and exhibitions April 4-8. Events will be held at Niagara Falls Public Libraries, the Niagara Falls Underground Railroad Heritage Center, the Aquarium of Niagara, the Niagara Power Vista, the Niagara Falls Culinary Institute and Niagara Falls State Park. There will also be day-of events, with the best vantage points at Niagara Falls State Park’s Terrapin Point, Prospect Point or Observation Tower. That evening, there will be a fireworks display on Old Falls Street in downtown Niagara Falls, courtesy of Wegmans.

▶ The new Niagara Parks Power Station + Tunnel will host several events, such as a mobile planetarium and interactive talks with NASA and CSA scientists, including a guest speaker who will discuss astronomy from an Indigenous perspective.

▶ In Syracuse, the Total Eclipse of the Park at historic NBT Bank Stadium will be on April 8. Gates to the ballpark open at 2:30 p.m. so fans can view the total solar eclipse, and the first 10,000 fans will receive commemorative eclipse glasses. Following the eclipse, the Syracuse Mets will play the Worcester Red Sox.

▶ On April 8, from noon until 4 p.m., the Museum of Science and Technology will host a free, family-friendly solar eclipse festival in downtown Syracuse.

Texas eclipse public events

▶ At Dallas’s Hôtel Swexan, hotel guests are invited to the 20th-floor rooftop to view the solar eclipse with complimentary glasses and a telescope. The hotel is also hosting a Breathe Meditation and Wellness event on the evening of the solar eclipse, where guests can participate in New Moon rituals, meditation, and a restorative sound bath.

▶ Downtown Dallas will host free events April 5-8 featuring live music, food trucks and family-friendly activities. The official watch party will take place at the Main Street Garden.

▶ The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Science Foundation and NASA will host the free Sun, Moon, and You solar eclipse viewing event at the historical Cotton Bowl Stadium in downtown Dallas with guest speaker Neil deGrasse Tyson. STEM organizations will be onsite throughout the stadium’s concourse with activities and handouts and telescopes will be available.

▶ Those who want to take to the skies can attend the 2024 Solar Eclipse Festival at Grapetown, a vineyard in Fredericksburg. Guests can take hot air balloon rides – weather permitting, of course – and experience a farm-to-table dinner, live music and wine tasting.

▶ In Bandera, the Ground Zero Music Fest will be a five-day music festival from April 4-9. The event schedule includes viewing the solar eclipse as well as a space-themed costume party.

▶ The town of Waco will host the Eclipse Over Texas event with telescopes and educational activities, food trucks and more. Astronomers from Lowell Observatory and Baylor University will also be in attendance.

▶ San Antonio’s Six Flags Fiesta Texas offers special eclipse packages to park guests who coincide their visit with the eclipse, offering souvenir T-shirts, eclipse glasses, a commemorative lanyard and a fireworks show.

▶ The Plaza San Antonio Hotel & Spa will open to the public for a free all-day eclipse event, including outdoor yoga, an astrology speaker and party.

▶ At Austin Central Library in Austin, there will be an eclipse viewing on April 8 open to the public with a solar telescope and activities for kids.

▶ Located in the path of totality, Arch Ray Resort in the Texas Hill Country will host a two-day Arch Ray Solar Eclipse Fest on April 7-8. Performers include the Goo Goo Dolls, Fastball, Switchfoot, Lane Smith and more. Guests have overnight accommodations for RV boondocking and access to the resort's winery, brewery, distillery and farm-to-table restaurant.

Indiana eclipse public events

▶ On April 8 at 3:06 p.m., Indianapolis will experience the total solar eclipse for three minutes and 46 seconds. Travelers can attend the Indy Eclipse Weekend taking place between April 5 and 8 around the city, also known as the “Racing Capital of the World.” Indianapolis Motor Speedway was chosen by NASA as one of the few broadcast locations, and NASA experts will be on-hand to answer questions about the scientific phenomenon.

▶ The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis will host an Eclipse Extravaganza on April 8 with giveaways and activities to celebrate the historic event.

▶ White River State Park will host Lunacy! on April 8 with viewing stations, more than 20 food trucks, yoga and Tabata classes, a brass quintet performance by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, and more.

▶ If a Burning Man-like festival is more your thing, head to the Indianapolis Museum of Art for the Total Eclipse of the Art, an event featuring fire performers, DJs, festivities, and food and drink vendors.

▶ The Indiana State Museum will offer hands-on Earth and moon activities and demonstrations throughout the day. When it’s time, guests can grab a spot on the front lawn to view the solar eclipse. The Indiana State Fairgrounds will also offer family activities throughout the day. A stage will host live music, a bar will serve drinks, and local food trucks will offer eclipse-themed offerings.

▶ Conner Prairie, a living history museum in Indianapolis, will host Hoosier astronaut Mark Brown, who will teach what life was like living and working in space. Guests can also experience a specialized dance performance created to reflect the theme of light and shadow, and they can get up and dance to songs by Stella Luna & the Satellites.

▶ On April 8, Indiana University in Bloomington will host the Hoosier Cosmic Celebration at Memorial Stadium. Actor William Shatner will narrate the eclipse, joined by artists and choreographers from IU. Shatner will also be joined by Grammy Award-nominated singer, songwriter and actress Janelle Monáe and former NASA astronaut Dr. Mae Jemison.

▶ Bloomington’s Switchyard Park will host a series of free eclipse-related events and activities leading up to the eclipse starting on April 5, including educational events and a movie screening of “Hidden Figures.” On April 8, there will be the Celestial Spectacle Solar Eclipse Viewing Event with food trucks, a beer garden, live music and eclipse viewing.

▶ An hour and a half from Cincinnati, the small city of Seymour is bracing itself for a threefold increase in population for the eclipse. The city will host a festival from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. on April 7 in anticipation of the eclipse, featuring educational programming, entertainment and food vendors.

Kentucky eclipse public events

▶ Louisville's Kentucky Science Center will have special programming available on April 8 included with general admission tickets.

▶ One of nine U.S. cities designated as a UNESCO Creative City, Paducah will host several eclipse-themed events. On April 7 and 8, a community street festival called X Marks the Spot will take over the riverfront. The National Quilt Museum will host a "Quilt on the Lawn" event for viewing the eclipse with visitors encouraged to bring a picnic quilt.

Ohio eclipse public events

▶ The Cleveland region is home to one of three national parks on the path, Cuyahoga Valley. Travelers to the region will experience the total eclipse for almost four minutes. They can also enjoy unobstructed views of the eclipse over Lake Erie.

▶ The Cleveland region is home to the only NASA visitors center on the path of totality, at the NASA Glenn Research Center. From April 6-8, visitors can enjoy special kid-friendly science programming from the visitors center and the Great Lakes Science Center at the Total Eclipse Fest. On April 7, the Cleveland Orchestra will perform a free “Out of this World” concert at the festival. Images from the Hubble Telescope and NASA archives will be accompanied by space-themed songs like the music from “Star Wars.”

▶ The University Circle neighborhood community and the Cleveland Museum of Natural History will host a Total on the Oval viewing party April 8 on Wade Oval, a central green space in Cleveland.

▶ The Richland County Fairgrounds in Mansfield will transform into a viewing party and campsite April 5-8 with live music, local vendors and food trucks.

▶ In Mansfield, the 900-acre Malabar Farm State Park will be in the path of totality and offer unobscured visibility. Visitors can bring blankets and patron food trucks on the day of the eclipse.

Arkansas eclipse public events

▶ Russellville will experience the eclipse for four minutes and 11 seconds of totality. The town will host the Eclipse Market 2024 from April 5 to 8 on its Main Street featuring local vendors and small businesses. On eclipse day, the city will host its first Moon Over Main festival with entertainment, food vendors, live music and NASA speakers.

▶The Ecliptic Festival is a four-day music, art and science festival April 5-8 in Hot Springs National Park. Presented by Atlas Obscura, the festival's lineup includes Angel Olsen, Dengue Fever, "Mythbusters" host Adam Savage as well as authors, filmmakers and astronomers.

Illinois eclipse public events

▶ Southern Illinois University Carbondale was on the path of totality for the 2017 solar eclipse, and it will be again this year. In partnership with NASA, the university will host the Southern Illinois Crossroads Eclipse Festival from April 5-8 with live entertainment and activities. When it’s time, guests can gather at Saluki Stadium for a guided eclipse experience with help from the Adler Planetarium of Chicago.

▶ The Shawnee Wine Trail near Pomona will also be on the path of totality, and its many wineries are offering unique celebrations for the event, including wine dinners, music events and RV parking.

Maine eclipse public events

▶ Parts of Maine will be in the path of totality. In fact, it'll be the last state in the U.S. to see the event. Green spaces across Aroostook County are being designated as “Star Parks” and will provide parking, trash and restroom facilities.

▶ Visitors to the small town of Houlton can witness the eclipse from Riverfront Park, Monument Park and Star Park on Main Street. Houlton International Airport will also have live music, food trucks, planes on display, and a “beautiful open sky view” during the eclipse.

▶ Presque Isle will have events starting April 3, including a free Eclipse Extravaganza at the Francis Malcolm Science Center on April 8 during the eclipse.

▶ The Versant Power Astronomy Center staff will be in Jackman on April 7 and 8 to host public stargazing and eclipse viewing.

Pennsylvania eclipse public events

▶ Erie is the only Pennsylvania city in the path of totality, including the entire shoreline of Lake Erie. Eclipse viewers can set up at Liberty Park, the park’s Highmark Amphitheater, the Bayfront Promenade and Bayfront District.

▶ Erie will host an eclipse-viewing event with Dr. David Horne, a Gannon University astronomer and professor, downtown at Perry Square on April 8. Solar-viewing telescopes will also be set up for people to see the celestial phenomenon. No eclipse-viewing glasses are required.

▶ Lake Erie Speedway on April 8 will have a viewing party and festival for the entire family.

▶ Mercyhurst University will also be opening its gates to the public for free eclipse-viewing from its Saxon Stadium. Activities include educational talks and classes.

▶ Also known for its wine country, Lake Erie will also host a three-day “Lights Out” eclipse and wine event, featuring 21 of its wineries, April 5-8. Each winery will offer an eclipse-themed food item with a tasting of three wines. Then, you can see the eclipse at your host winery.

Washington, D.C., eclipse public events

▶ Although the nation's capital will not be in the path of totality, it will experience a partial solar eclipse. The city is hosting the free Solar Eclipse Festival on the National Mall on April 8 from noon until 4 p.m. In partnership with the Smithsonian Museums, there will be activity stations and educational programming, including telescope viewing.

Kathleen Wong is a travel reporter for USA TODAY based in Hawaii. You can reach her at kwong@usatoday.com.

search_result.title: Oregon solar eclipse updates on traffic, crowds, event details and ...
search_result.text:
Statesman Journal

Friday's blog: Updates from around Oregon

Saturday blog: Solar eclipse updates from around Oregon

Group skydives during eclipse

Most people spent Monday's solar eclipse looking up at the sky. However, Marshall Miller and five of his friends decided to descend from the sky during totality.

The group, working with Outside TV, fell 14,000 feet above the ground in Madras, Oregon, to become the first-ever wingsuit formation through a full solar eclipse.

They jumped exactly 30 seconds before totality, to coincide with the changes in the sun.

Amateur astronomer enjoys sky before, during eclipse

SALEM, 2:45 p.m. — Bailey Steutzman of Salem has camped in the Southeast Salem dog park for the last two days getting ready for this event.

The amateur astronomer brought his telescope, his solar filter, a few friends and his daughter, Deanna, then prepared for the upcoming event. But the night before, he was enjoying the night sky.

"We star gazed until 4 o'clock, staring at these big masses of stars," Steutzman said.

Steutzman slept for three hours before he woke for the eclipse, which he watched with his family and friends. Once he finished with his telescope and totality, he looked around him and watched what he called the sunset.

"Some caught mercury and Venus, but I caught the sunset, this 360 golden band through the trees," Steutzman said. "It was incredible."

— Brooke Jackson-Glidden

Eclipse, baseball bring family together

KEIZER – It was a collective reaction of astonishment as fans viewed Totality at Volcanoes Stadium.

Totality arrived at 10:17 a.m. during the first eclipse delay in baseball history featuring the host Salem-Keizer Volcanoes vs. the Hillsboro Hops.

“That was amazing,” said Chase Schechter of Wilsonville, who attended the game with her grandmother, Joan Bouchard. “I was surprised that people were coming from all over the world to see this, but now that I’ve seen it I would definitely go again.”

Joan Bouchard wanted to share the historic occasion with her granddaughter.

“It was very moving,” Bouchard said. “I will never be around to see another one, so this was very important to me.”

The first morning game in Volcanoes history was delayed at 10:03 a.m. and play resumed 51 minutes later in the bottom of the first inning.

Fans representing 34 states and eight countries were in attendance at sold-out Volcanoes Stadium.

— Gary Horowitz

Despite some road congestion, visitors satsified with eclipse

SALEM, 1:30 p.m. — Lod Emily Conde from Tigard weren't planning to come to the eclipse, but a guide at the Oregon Observatory persuaded them.



"I asked him, 'Is it worth it?' And he said, 'yes.' So we drove down," Lou Conde said.

The two camped in the dog park, which was almost empty at 12:22 p.m. The remaining campers and guests have said crowds were much smaller than expected here, though the parking lot was full by morning.

Bikers and hikers emerged from the driveway to a hectic scene, as cars slowly nudged forward along River Road. The stretch near the park had become a makeshift parking lot, with several guests waiting patiently for cars.

Lisa Aziz of Los Angeles waited for her husband to retrieve her car with her two daughters, Liora and Ariela. The family drove down this morning at 5:30 a.m.

Camper or day tripper, the reaction to totality was the same, said Lou Conde.

"It was awesome," Conde said. "The whole crowd oohed and she's as soon as it slipped into totality."

— Brooke Jackson-Glidden

They came, they eclipsed, they're outta here

SALEM’S RIVERFRONT PARK, 12:30 p.m. – Visitors broke camp at Salem’s Riverfront Park, though some stragglers remained in the early afternoon.

Tents abounded here Monday morning, but just after noon, many had vanished.

Thea Nelson-Jerry and her family had set up Saturday evening. But they didn’t waste much time after the total eclipse. They dismantled their spacious tent, preparing to return to the Muckleshoot Reservation in Washington.

— Jonathan Bach

Beauty of eclipse moves some to tears

Finding the words to describe the experience of totality wasn't easy for campers at Solartown just outside of Madras, Oregon.

"Short of the birth of my kids, it was the most beautiful thing I've seen in my life," David Wiza Of Beaverton said. "I'm an emotional baby anyway, but holy cow."

He and his wife, Kathy, hugged — but only after totality was over.

They refrained from taking photos so they could enjoy the experience.

"I didn't want to waste any time looking away," he said.

He learned his lesson watching the 2010 Shuttle Endeavor launch, which he said was the last night launch of a space shuttle.

"I have fond memories as it appeared through my viewfinder," he said. "And I just wasn't going to do that again. I told myself I was going to look.”

Karri White, a banker from Santa Cruz, California, choked up and wiped away tears after she and her family and friends did a group hug during totality.

"It was the most beautiful experience I've had," she said. "In the midst of it, I teared up. It was just a glorious feeling."

"It reminds me of why I became a physicist," said her son, Cameron White, who just graduated from UC Santa Cruz and is headed to graduate school at San Diego State University.

Cameron was impressed viewing Saturn's rings through a super high-powered telescope at UCSC.

"I thought Saturn was the most beautiful thing I've ever seen. This was 100 times better."

— Capi Lynn

Anticipation, wait for eclipse worth it for Baskett Slough visitors

BASKETT SLOUGH, 12:10 p.m. — The turkey vultures went to roost a little after 10 a.m. at Baskett Slough Wildlife Refuge. Then the crickets began to chirp, visitors pulled on sweaters and the sun disappeared from the sky.

The anticipation had built on a hill near an observation deck in the hour prior. Scattered groups talked and took selfies in the grassy area.

"It's getting dark isn't it?" said one girl in the last minutes before totality. There was a collective shout of "Venus!" as many fingers quickly pointed to a sudden bright spot in the sky. Then glasses clinked in a toast as the shadow aligned over the sun entirely.

When the light came back, everyone stood around, amazed.

Laura Newton, traveling from Washington state with her recently married sister and brother-in-law, was speechless at first.

"I don't think I've ever seen something that was so awesome in my entire life," she said. "It left me in awe."

On the other side of the hill, Joanna Picchi was wishing it had gone a little longer.

"It was beyond expectations. But it all happened so fast. I just wanted it to stay for a while to soak it all up," she said. "It was really a spiritual experience."

Within minutes, most of the visitors had begun to trickle off the butte and down the hill.

Miel Corbett, a Fish and Wildlife spokeswoman, stood nearby, collecting trash from people and thanking them for visiting.

"We've never seen so many people on Baskett Butte at one time," she laughed.

As most of the groups filed out down the trails, the sun was beating down bright again. Besides the fireworks in the distance, it looked like a normal, albeit busy, day at the wildlife refuge.

— Cooper Green

Even during eclipse, Girl Scouts have cookies

About two dozen Girl Scouts got an extra special view of the eclipse, watching with Gov. Kate Brown and other dignitaries on a private patio at the Capitol.

“It’s such a fun place to see the eclipse,” said Rhyanne Vanness, 7, of Woodburn.

As the moon crept slowly across the sun, they gave the Governor Girl Scout cookies and posed for pictures.

A hush settled over the crowd as totality approached, then cheers and even some sobs broke out.

“I thought it was amazing,” Genevieve Trentzsch, 10, of Woodburn said afterward. “It was like a whole different world.”

The U.S. Postal Service also presented Brown with a framed commemorative postmark celebrating Salem’s place in the path of totality. The stamps are available in the Capitol Galleria until 1:30 p.m. today.

Before her private event, Brown made a quick trip outside the Capitol building, where hundreds of eclipse watchers settled in.

— Tracy Loew

Crowds at Willamette in awe of eclipse

SALEM, 11:45 a.m. – The kind of applause usually only reserved for the world’s biggest musical acts was delivered for a natural phenomenon.

Thousands of people – old and young, of all different socioeconomic status and from all over the world – gathered on the lawns of Willamette University Monday morning to watch the total solar eclipse, and they got a show no rock band could ever deliver.

Few knew the magnitude of what was coming; most didn’t.

But when the world went dark and only a ring of light hung in the sky, the crowd that had been cheering throughout the countdown rose to a fever pitch.

“They’ll tell their grandchildren about what they saw on the 21st of August, 2017,” said Paddy Brennan, who came to Salem from Ireland with 36 members of the Cork Astronomy Club.

“This is an extraordinary event. It might encourage them to do science because science is something that’s helping us along in every field.”

Coming 5,000 or so miles to bear witness something so dependent on weather would seem a risk to most.

Seeing the moon completely block out the sun for almost two minutes was worth the expense, time and planning for the Irish, and if they weren’t committed before, they’re hooked now.

“We’re looking forward to seven year’s time,” said Margaret Jackson, one of the 36 Irish club members on hand. “We’re looking forward to New York.”

In 2006 Brennan traveled to Turkey from Ireland to witness a total eclipse. He said the one in Salem wasn’t as long, but it was darker.

And the atmosphere of the crowd at Willamette magnified the event.

“That’s extraordinary, it’s an extraordinary happening in nature,” Brennan said. “And you wonder why people travel the world to see these. Totality. Up in Portland you’d have a partial eclipse, maybe 99, but it’s not the same.

“It’s an extraordinary event and you have to experience totality to understand.”

— Bill Poehler

An eclipse skeptic, until she saw it in person

SALEM’S RIVERFRONT PARK — When Kev Brock’s husband pushed to see Monday’s total solar eclipse, she thought he was going a little overboard. She read stories about people who cried and cheered, and remembered thinking they were “overly dramatic.”

“But that was one of the most incredible things I’ve ever seen. It made me cry and my children cheered along with the rest of the crowd,” Brock said in a text after the eclipse plunged Salem’s Riverfront Park into darkness, revealing the crisp white atmosphere of the sun.

“It was amazing to be amongst a crowd of people who felt the same,” Brock said.

Mark Strickland, 27, of Irvine, California, put it in simple terms: “That was phenomenal, being able to go through that experience.”

His friend, Kip Whittier, felt sorry for anyone on the planet who didn’t experience the phenomenon.

“It’s not gonna happen again for so long,” the 23-year-old said.

-Jonathan Bach

Crowds take to area highways after the eclipse

SALEM, 11:10 a.m. — As predicted by officials, eclipse viewers began taking to road shortly after the completion of totality over the Mid-Willamette Valley.

ODOT's TripCheck showed heavy congestion on stretches of Interstate 5 heading north and south out of the Salem area.

Traffic through the Salem on surface streets was moderate but flowing smoothly.

No crashes have been reported as of 11:00 a.m.

Salem's solar eclipse is over: Now what?

Baseball, eclipse bring family a special moment

KEIZER - "Look at that! Oh my God! That was amazing!"

Those were some of the reactions from fans as totality arrived Monday at Volcanoes Stadium during the first Eclipse Game in baseball history, featuring the host Salem-Keizer Volcanoes vs. the Hillsboro Hops.

Joan Bouchard wanted to share the historic moment with her granddaughter.

"It was very moving. I will never be around to see another one, so this was very important to me," Bouchard said.

Her granddaughter, Chase Schechter from Wilsonville, called the total solar eclipse "the coolest thing ever."

"I was surprised that people were coming from all over the world to see this, but now that I've seen it I would definitely go again," Chase said.

Fans from 34 states and eight countries were in attendance at Volcanoes Stadium when Totality arrived at 10:17 a.m.

- Gary Horowitz

Crowds at the Oregon State Fairgrounds begin to view the eclipse

As the eclipse began shortly after 9 a.m. Monday morning, Charles Valle helped his two children, Ivan and Olive, put their viewing glasses on. They turned their faces upwards.

"I see it," Ivan, 4, said to his dad.

"What does it look like," Charles asked, as his wife Kathleen grabbed food from a nearby breakfast stand. "Does it look like someone took a bite out of the sun?"

"Yeah!" cheered Ivan and Olive, 2.

"That's the moon getting in the way," Charles said.

— Natalie Pate

Eclipse visitors give out extra glasses

Tracy Bartlett, of Joshua Tree, California, hands out her group's extra eclipse viewer glasses to strangers at Bush's Pasture Park.

She and her friends drove up Saturday to avoid traffic and set up camp in the park's lower field. "I'm glad they opened up the park to camping," she said, adding that she's enjoyed the pleasant weather and walking paths of the city.

She and her friends walked downtown yesterday and saw a movie.

They plan to wait until the first wave of traffic leaves before heading to Eugene.

— Whitney Woodworth

Some eclipse watchers are more serious than others

SOLARTOWN, MADRAS 9:30 a.m. - Some people are so serious about observing the eclipse they don't have time to chat.

I stopped to introduce myself to a gentleman with a fancy telescope and camera setup, and he ignored my greetings.

He had earplugs in, so I waved to get his attention.

One of his camping neighbors said he was still trying to get set up, offering a hint of apology.

I explained I was with the media, and then the gentleman acknowledged my presence and said: "Maybe later."

— Capi Lynn

Silverton students launch balloon for eclipse experiment

SILVERTON – Silverton High School was the launch site of a high-altitude balloon Monday morning, and the launch went off without a hitch at 8:45 a.m.

The high school program was one of 55 teams nationwide that built balloons that will capture data and video of the eclipse, which will be utilized by NASA.

“It actually went as textbook as it could have gone,” project coordinator Creighton Helms said.

Helms said the project faced obstacles in the weeks and days leading up to the launch: wind forecasts that would have pushed the balloon to restricted airspace above wildfires, GPS units not working and having to be overnighted to NASA for repair and overnighted back, and a camera that required repair up until 1 a.m. on launch day.

No problem.

“Everything just came together and allowed us to be able to fly,” Helms said. “The winds were light and the conditions were good and everything that we had practiced went exactly as we had done. The balloon lifted off the ground like a pillow.”

Hundreds gathered at the soccer fields at Silverton High to witness the event, and an enthusiastic countdown helped set the balloon off for launch. A project that began 10 months ago, which was months behind other projects around the country, went off without a problem.

Next comes retrieval of the balloon and its cameras and tracking contents. With conditions calmer than expected, that should happen later today, and Helms said it could come down a mere 10 miles away from the high school.

— Lee Clarkson

Family makes last-minute decision to view eclipse from Englewood Park

SALEM, 9:40 a.m. — When the McFarland family of Snohomish, Washington set up camp in North Salem's Englewood Park, they didn't know they legally could.

When Jesse and Briana McFarland drove down from Northern Washington with their three kids and dog, they had a reservation at Salem RV. When they saw the spot, they decided to scout for a new location.

"Our plan was ill-defined," Jesse McFarland said over breakfast in the park. "We wanted to get to the path of totality, and Salem hit the sweet spot for us."

Englewood Park, a small wooded park near the elementary school, was mostly vacant Sunday evening. The family drove around until they found the spot, saw another pitched tent and hoped for the best.

"If we had known, and we had found this park again, we would have done the exact same thing," Jesse McFarland said.

— Brooke Jackson-Glidden

Don't have eclipse glasses? Find a tree

SALEM, 9:10 a.m. – If you get tired of wearing your eclipse glasses, there’s another way to enjoy the event: Find a tree.

Stand under a tree during the eclipse and you might experience what Jim Todd, with the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, calls a “natural pinhole.”

That’s because trees and their leaves can act like pinhole projectors during solar eclipses. Each gap in the leaves acts like a pinhole, projecting the image of eclipsed sun below.

Chris Fuld, who camped in Salem with a tent and sleeping bag to catch Monday’s eclipse, has experienced it before: “You’ll see little suns.”

Fuld, of Bellevue, Washington, first saw it with leaves in Atlanta, Georgia, during a partial eclipse decades ago.

“(It was) very similar to like what you see when you see the Northern Lights for the first time,” he said. “You don’t really process it."

— Jonathan Bach

► What to watch for:See four planets and other stars

Visitor invests in Volcanoes eclipse memorabilia

KEIZER, 8:50 p.m. — When Jeremy Schmidt entered the gates of Volcanoes Stadium at 5 a.m., one of the first things he did was load up with Eclipse Game souvenirs.

He purchased an Eclipse jersey for himself, and assorted t-shirts, sweat shirts, a baseball and small bat for family members. The $300-plus investment was worth it to commemorate the first Eclipse Game in baseball history.

“I figured I’d buy something. I wasn’t sure what,” said Schmidt, who made the drive from Seattle. “I bought something for the whole family.”

It was Schmidt’s first game at Volcanoes Stadium and he purchased tickets for the Eclipse Game eight months ago.

“A friend of our told us about it and we were like, let’s do something because we wanted to see the solar eclipse down here anyways,” he said.

— Gary Horowitz

Capitol Mall still has room and free eclipse glasses

The Capitol Mall is filling slowly, but there is plenty of room left, and free eclipse glasses are available.



On the mall, people lined up to take part in a free Aztec cleansing ceremony performed by Portlander Javier Rojas and his family.



Others settled in with small tents, air mattresses and lawn chairs.



Ellen Vyas traveled down from Seattle Saturday night to stay with friends. Her four kids seemed more excited about the viewing glasses than the eclipse, she said.



Ron and Stacey Alley, of McMinnville, put up a tent to sell eclipse art, T-shirts and snacks. Business was good and the T-shirts were almost gone, Alley said.



Janellia Lejsea Capelle waited for eclipse glasses in a line that snaked down Court Street. Her four kids were jumping with excitement.



While all eyes were focused on the east, Ryan Jackson set up a 360 degree video camera in the middle of the crowd.



Jackson, of Edmonton, Alberta, is tasked with filming the crowd for a Montreal Planetarium documentary.



“While everyone else is watching the eclipse, I’ll be watching them,” he said.



- Tracy Loew

Fairgrounds draws eclipse visitors from around the world

Amateur astronomer Robert Nelson requested Monday, Aug. 21, off from work nearly a year ago. He and his wife, Afton, were not going to miss it.



Monday morning, Robert was spotted setting up a telescope at the Rose City Astronomer's booth at the Oregon State Fairgrounds. He was setting it up for attendees to view Venus, which looked like a small speck of light when looking through the telescope.



They, like many others, left early Sunday afternoon to get from Portland to Salem. When pleasantly surprised by the lack of cars sitting bumper-to-bumper on the freeway, they stopped in Woodburn for a few hours to visit family.



Thousands of other people and families were at the fairgrounds Monday as well.



Ulrike and Sylvio Redanz from Germany were spotted taking photos with their 6- and 2-year-old children in front of an eclipse-themed backdrop near the ground's entrance. The family is stationed in Portland for work for three years as Sylvio studies oral bacteria for Oregon Health & Science University, but he said it was a "happy coincidence" that the eclipse happened while they were in the state.



Adrian Peña and his wife, Mitsue Shibata, brought their 10-year-old daughter to Salem from Vancouver, Washington, and are staying in Sublimity. They both have seen partial eclipses but never a total eclipse.

— Natalie Pate

Campers well behaved in Salem parks

SALEM, 8:30 A.M. — More than 2,000 people camped overnight in city parks, according to city officials. Staff found 2,300 campers in 15 of the city's 93 parks, mostly in the largest ones: Bush's Pasture Park, Riverfront Park and Minto-Brown Island Park. No problems were reported.

No parking is available in Minto-Brown or Lansing parks.

City officials remind campers than normal park rules go into effect later today — meaning sprinklers will be turned on tonight.

— Statesman Journal

Family is waiting for some eclipse magic

SOLARTOWN, MADRAS, 8: 10 a.m. - The Maire family spent some time Sunday night on top of their motor home, checking out the view.

That's where they plan to be come go time for the eclipse. Gina and Justin Maire, from San Luis Obispo, California, brought their four children to Solartown for this once-in-a-lifetime celestial experience.

Malia and Mikayla are 13-year-old twins, Jake is 11, and Bode is 7.

Malia said she was looking forward to watching the magic that is supposed to happen around Mount Jefferson during the eclipse.

— Capi Lynn

Eclipse game lures indifferent baseball fan

KEIZER, 7:40 a.m. — Karin Bond arrived at Volcanoes Stadium early Monday morning to witness the first game in baseball history delayed due to a total solar eclipse.

“Actually, I’ve only been to two other baseball games in my life,” said Bond, who was in town from Aurora, Colorado. “Once with my father, once with my husband.”

Her last baseball game prior to Monday came in the 1960s.

“I thought it would be fun to see the eclipse with my friend Virginia,” Bond said. “We’ve traveled all over the world together.”

Bond acknowledged that it “seems pretty odd” to be in a baseball stadium, much less at 7 a.m. for a 9:35 a.m. opening pitch. The Salem-Keizer Volcanoes will be playing the Hillsboro Hops in a Northwest League game.

Bond qualifies as an eclipse chaser of sorts. It will be the third total solar eclipse she's witnessed in person, the most recent one coming in 2006 in Turkey.

— Gary Horowitz

Eclipse adventure wins over La La Land

SALEM’S RIVERFRONT PARK, 7:01 a.m. – Equipped with an eclipse-viewing telescope and binoculars – plus black coffee and a chai latte – Michael Bergeron and Kevin Lewis were two among many at Salem’s Riverfront Park in the early morning hours Monday awaiting a total solar eclipse.

The pair, from San Francisco, rolled into town on an early bus – Lewis figures it was about 2 a.m. – after visiting friends in Portland. They chose Salem and the eclipse over a trip to Los Angeles.

“(It) was an adventure instead of a stupid vacation,” Lewis said.

Many ventured to Riverfront Park this weekend to pitch their camps, transforming this park on the Willamette River into a tent village.

The weather bodes well: Skies last night offered a view of the stars, even over a light-pollution heavy city like Salem. The view is similarly clear this morning, meaning those binoculars and the telescope are sure to get a lot of use.

“So little in life these days lives up to the hype,” Lewis said.

But the eclipse, he thinks, is different.

— Jonathan Bach

Salem airport is buzzing

SALEM, 7:15 a.m. — Planes are arriving at a brisk clip at Salem Municipal Airport.

About 115 planes are expected to touch down for the total solar eclipse, in addition to the 175 that are based here.

Among the visitors expected is a group of scientists from California that will be shuttled in on a corporate jet, and members of a flying club from Washington that will be traveling in 30 small aircraft.

While most of the incoming will be on “mom and pop” planes, some of the larger aircraft expected to land at McNary Field for the eclipse include a Beechcraft 1900, a Gulf Stream 450, a Learjet 35, and maybe even a Boeing 737.

— Statesman Journal

Trash stacks up, toilets back up

SOLARTOWN, MADRAS, 6:30 a.m. - What a relief that eclipse day is here.

Organizers at Solartown are no longer able to keep up with the sanitation needs of campers in more than 5,000 RV and tent sites.

Piles of garbage are growing throughout the campground, and the porta potties are on the verge of overflowing and out of toilet paper.

The only dumpster appears to be the one behind the food vendors, and the Madras FFA students who were volunteering to empty the cardboard garbage bins seem to have disappeared.

The mobile shower also was shut down sometime Sunday. Earlier in the day, drainage in many of the stalls was a problem.

Other inconveniences that have everyone thankful the eclipse is happening today include a four-hour wait for vehicles to get back into Solartown and an hour-long wait at one of the two coffee huts.

— Capi Lynn

Baseball fans arrive before sunrise

KEIZER, 6 A.M. – Fans began arriving at 5 a.m. Monday at Volcanoes Stadium for the first Eclipse Game in baseball history.

Signs were posted en route to the ballpark on Keizer Station Boulevard noting that the game was sold out. At 6 a.m. cars were backed up waiting to enter the parking lot.

All fans were given safety glasses to view the total solar eclipse.

Volcanoes officials said the baseball from today's opening pitch, and the first ball used after the eclipse delay, will be sent to the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, New York.

- Gary Horowitz

Taiko drums and ice sculptures at the fairgrounds

OREGON STATE FAIRGROUNDS, 6:45 a.m. -- As the sun rose over the Oregon State Fair fairgrounds Monday morning, Portland Taiko drummers beat the traditional Japanese instrument on the stage of the amphitheater.

Chants and staging created an entrancing performance to kick off the 2017 total solar eclipse festivities.

A line wrapped around the 17th street entrance of the fairgrounds, with 9,000 people expected to attend the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry's solar viewing party in Salem. The event has been sold out for months.

In addition to rows of booths with everything from teriyaki chicken and yakisoba noodles to tables with telescopes and scientific demonstrations, participants were greeted with numerous activities upon entry.

Immediately inside, attendees will see ICEovation artists carving two ice sculptures -- one of the sun and the other of a small person with his or her arms up.

James Stugart, owner of the custom ice sculpture business, said he and his artists, Tommi Stugart and Randee Metayer, will finish carving the sculpture and when the time is right (AKA as close to totality as possible).

— Natalie Pate

OSU:Scientists to study 'breath of land'

Traffic passable, coffee is crowded

DOWNTOWN, 6 a.m. — At the dawn of the Great American Eclipse, downtown Salem traffic was moving smoothly, if not a little light for this time of day.

People had been parking on the street since late Sunday night with a great number of people sleeping in their cars in front of the state Capital to beat the traffic.

The only places where people were really congregating: coffee shops.

But there’s a twist: The line to get coffee was five minutes; the line for the bathroom was 10 minutes.

— Bill Poehler

Refuge fills before dawn

DALLAS, 6:30 a.m. — The parking lot was full long before the stars disappeared at Baskett Slough.

Eclipse fiends from all over flocked to the wildlife refuge west of Salem, lining the tight gravel roads with parked cars and campers.

"It wasn't planned, but it was expected. We only planned for the parking lots," said Ken Robins, a federal wildlife officer. "It's way more visitation than we're used to."

The small parking lot filled around 3 a.m., based on the arrival of some visitors.

Karl Brown, from Portland, said he arrived during that time and found a space. Brown said he'd just learned about the eclipse recently and thought this would be a good viewing spot.

"Figured it'd probably be less busy than anywhere else, less busy than big national campgrounds," he said.

Robins estimated the slough was host to around 500 visitors by 6 a.m. He guessed Ankeny Wildlife Refuge nearby had a similar number.

"Mostly we're just trying to avoid people from going in areas that are habitat for endangered butterflies and just trying to avoid fires, that's the main concern," he said.

— Cooper Green

Solartown creates a city the size of Woodburn

SOLARTOWN, MADRAS, 5:30 a.m. — More than 20,000 people, who will soon be waking up to prepare for the first coast-to-coast total solar eclipse in 99 years, are calling this temporary city home.

That would make it about the size of Woodburn.

The population estimate of Solartown, a makeshift campground just outside Madras, is based on there being more than 5,000 RV and tent sites and an average of four people per site.

There are 28 cities in Oregon with more than 20,000 residents, according to the Population Research Center at Portland State University, and 17 with at least 30,000.

Woodburn has a population of 24,795. Other 20,000-resident-plus cities in Oregon that Solartown compares to include nearby Redmond, as well as Wilsonville, Newberg and Ashland.

Salem has a population of 162,060 and Keizer 37,505.

Cloud cover not expected to impact view

SALEM, 4:45 a.m. — The National Weather Service says Oregon could see areas of thin cloud cover, high in the sky Monday.

"However, these should not be thick enough to limit visibility of the eclipse," the agency said on Twitter late Sunday.

Yaquina Lighthouse:The first place to see the darkness

Coffee shop recalls eclipse glasses

SALEM, 4:30 a.m. — Dutch Bros Coffee is warning customers to not use glasses the company handed out from stands after the company was unable to authenticate the necessary certification.

Eclipse glasses should have a specific ISO (international standards organization) certification, with number 12312-2. Other companies, including Amazon, also issued recalls after counterfeit glasses ended up in the hands of consumers.

The company issued a voluntary recall on their Facebook page late Sunday.

"If you received a pair of these glasses, DO NOT USE THEM TO VIEW THE ECLIPSE," the post stated.

The company will take glasses back at the location originally obtained for a free drink.

Eclipse glasses:How to spot unsafe fakes

Small but steady traffic traveling I-5 south

SALEM, 4:15 a.m. — Predawn Salem streets early Monday were slightly busier than the usual weekday morning.

A small but steady stream of cars left southbound Interstate 5 exits in north Salem just before 4 a.m.

The 24-hour Denny's location just off the Market Street exit saw packed tables as the occasional group of cars left the interstate and headed for destinations across town.

Oregon Department of Transportation's TripCheck website showed no slowdowns or crashes on area highways.

While the anticipated crowds failed to materialize in the Mid-Willamette Valley over the weekend, officials were still following plans to have resources in place should crowds make the decision to drive down today for the eclipse.

— David Davis

More:Procrastinator's guide to the solar eclipse

Driving:Keep your eyes on the road during eclipse

Post Office offering eclipse postmark and stamp

SALEM, 4 a.m. — A special postmark will be available on Aug. 21 to celebrate the total eclipse, joining the already available Total Eclipse Forever Stamps. The collectible postmark will be available during a special celebration in the Galleria of the Capitol from 8:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., or all day at the Salem Main Post Office and 29 other post offices in Oregon and Washington. You can also get the postmark by mailing a self-addressed stamped envelope by inside a larger envelope by Sept. 21 to:

ECLIPSE POSTMARK

PO BOX 9998

SALEM OR 97301-9998

— Don Currie

►Don't have eclipse glasses?:Make your own pinhole viewer

Five eclipse facts

How: A solar eclipse occurs when the moon passes between the sun and the Earth at a particular angle. The moon blocks the light from the sun, casting a shadow on the Earth that, in the path of totality, turns day into twilight. It's only by coincidence that the moon is able to do this. The sun is 400 times wider than the moon, but it is also 400 times farther away, so they appear to be the same size in the sky.

Last time in Oregon: It was Feb. 26, 1979, which also crossed Washington, Idaho, Montana and North Dakota. It was the dead of winter, so not surprisingly the weather was described as "bleak."

Why "Great American Eclipse?": This is the first total solar eclipse to only pass over the United States and no other nation since the country was founded.

The path of totality: The shadow of the moon as it entirely blocks the sun's light will sweep across parts of 12 states: Oregon, Idaho, Wyoming, Nebraska, Kansas, Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky, Tennessee, Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina.

Some Oregon cities in the pathinclude: Lincoln City, Newport, Dallas, Salem, Albany, Lebanon, Sweet Home, Madras, Fossil, Baker City and Ontario.

Speedy shadow: The moon's shadow hauls. It will average more than 1,600 mph, but will actually slow down as it travels across the country because of the relationship between the earth's and moon's rotations and the planet's curvature. In Oregon, the speed will top 2,200 mph, just less than three times the speed of sound. It will take 91 minutes for the eclipse to cross the country, but it will only be visible for a couple minutes at any given location.

For the love of science

Christopher Shang loves science, and he couldn’t pass up the opportunity to watch Monday’s total solar eclipse.

The Bellevue, Washington, resident was camping with friends and family Sunday afternoon at Woodmansee Park in South Salem, where about a dozen tents were set up.

“We saw an article in Time (magazine) about the eclipse, and it was like, ‘Oh, hey, there is an eclipse heading down through Oregon,’” Shang said. “So we might as well come down here and check it out. It’s a rare occurrence, in the United States anyway.”

Shang said his group chose Woodmansee Park because they didn’t want to have to fight eclipse traffic Monday morning, which could have happened had they stayed in a hotel.

Despite having the options of going to either central Oregon or the coast, Shang and his group chose Salem so they could be closer to Portland.

“We wanted to head to Portland either way, because Portland is a cool place,” Shang said. “So we decided to head to Salem to see the eclipse, and then knock Portland off the list at the same time.”

— Pete Martini
